articles.headline: S.E.C. Has a Message for Firms Not Used to Admitting Guilt
articles.snippet: By requiring an admission of guilt in some cases, the S.E.C.’s new chairwoman is pressing for more accountability at financial firms.
articles.abstract: By requiring an admission of guilt in some cases, the S.E.C.’s new chairwoman is pressing for more accountability at financial firms.
articles.lead_paragraph: The days of cop-out settlements in big securities cases may be waning.

articles.headline: Disappointing Fall for ‘Rock Center,’ a News Program With Big Ambitions
articles.snippet: The NBC show was an ambitious effort to mimic the breadth of “60 Minutes,” but it never generated much of an audience. Friday was its last night.
articles.abstract: The NBC show was an ambitious effort to mimic the breadth of “60 Minutes,” but it never generated much of an audience. Friday was its last night.
articles.lead_paragraph: If “Rock Center With Brian Williams” has proved anything in the last year and a half, it is this: However hard it is to gather an audience for any kind of show in prime time, for news programming, the task is even harder.

articles.headline: Limiting the 401(k) Finder’s Fee
articles.snippet: A wave of lawsuits and a federal effort have helped lower fees for 401(k)’s and pushed companies to offer clearer details about plans, but progress is uneven.
articles.abstract: A wave of lawsuits and a federal effort have helped lower fees for 401(k)’s and pushed companies to offer clearer details about plans, but progress is uneven.
articles.lead_paragraph: Given the speed with which 401(k) accounts have been replacing pensions, workers can only hope that their employers have assembled a low-cost diversified portfolio that will keep earning money over time — perhaps a long time, given the number of people living to their 90s and beyond.

articles.headline: Ex-Contractor Is Charged in Leaks on N.S.A. Surveillance
articles.snippet: Edward J. Snowden, whose release of classified files has sparked a debate over the proper limits of government monitoring, was charged with violating the Espionage Act and theft of government property.
articles.abstract: Edward J. Snowden, whose release of classified files has sparked a debate over the proper limits of government monitoring, was charged with violating the Espionage Act and theft of government property.
articles.lead_paragraph: Edward J. Snowden, the former National Security Agency contractor whose leak of agency documents has set off a national debate over the proper limits of government surveillance, has been charged with violating the Espionage Act and stealing government property for disclosing classified information to The Guardian and The Washington Post, the Justice Department said on Friday.

articles.headline: Confidence From Chief of SoftBank in Sprint Bid
articles.snippet: Most analysts agree that SoftBank faces long odds as it seeks to compete in the American mobile market, but the company’s chief has been successful in taking on giant companies — and coming out on top.
articles.abstract: Most analysts agree that SoftBank faces long odds as it seeks to compete in the American mobile market, but the company’s chief has been successful in taking on giant companies — and coming out on top.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — In 2005, SoftBank was in dire straits. The scrappy Internet services company had booked a $1 billion loss the previous year, its largest ever. A campaign to enter Japan’s strictly regulated cellphone business had failed. Its share price, which had soared with the Internet bubble, had fallen to less than a tenth of its height in 2000.

articles.headline: In Turnabout, Syria Rebels Get Libyan Weapons
articles.snippet: Weapons formerly in Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s stockpile are making their way to antigovernment forces in Syria, financed largely by Qatar, which has strong ties with Libyan rebel groups.
articles.abstract: Weapons formerly in Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s stockpile are making their way to antigovernment forces in Syria, financed largely by Qatar, which has strong ties with Libyan rebel groups.
articles.lead_paragraph: During his more than four decades in power, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi of Libya was North Africa’s outrageously self-styled arms benefactor, a donor of weapons to guerrillas and terrorists around the world fighting governments he did not like.
articles.byline: By C. J. Chivers, Eric Schmitt and Mark Mazzetti

articles.headline: How Angry Is Brazil? Pelé Now Has Feet of Clay
articles.snippet: As Brazilian protests grow, even soccer comes under fire after Edson Arantes do Nascimento, the soccer legend known as Pelé, told Brazilians to “forget the protests.”
articles.abstract: As Brazilian protests grow, even soccer comes under fire after Edson Arantes do Nascimento, the soccer legend known as Pelé, told Brazilians to “forget the protests.”
articles.lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — It has long been a source of unparalleled pride, a common bond uniting a disparate nation, something Brazilians could always point to — even in times of economic ruin or authoritarian rule — that made them the best in the world.
articles.byline: By Simon Romero and William Neuman

articles.headline: A Fit of Pique on Wall Street
articles.snippet: Perhaps more than at any time since the financial crisis, Wall Street knows it must prepare for a world without the Federal Reserve’s largess.
articles.abstract: Perhaps more than at any time since the financial crisis, Wall Street knows it must prepare for a world without the Federal Reserve’s largess.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the Federal Reserve said this week that the economy could soon be strong enough to live with less of its stimulus, the markets threw their version of a tantrum.

articles.headline: Data Security Is a Classroom Worry, Too
articles.snippet: Experts warn that educators may be embracing technology without doing enough to secure student data.
articles.abstract: Experts warn that educators may be embracing technology without doing enough to secure student data.
articles.lead_paragraph: LIKE many privacy-minded parents of elementary students, Tony Porterfield tries to keep close tabs on the personal information collected about his two sons. So when he heard that their school district in Los Altos, Calif., had adopted Edmodo, an online learning network connecting more than 20 million teachers and students around the world, he decided to check out the program.

articles.headline: For Dell Investors, a Safety Valve
articles.snippet: An alternative is available to Dell Inc. investors disappointed with Michael Dell’s buyout offer: they can ask a court to appraise the company’s long-term value.
articles.abstract: An alternative is available to Dell Inc. investors disappointed with Michael Dell’s buyout offer: they can ask a court to appraise the company’s long-term value.
articles.lead_paragraph: AFTER months of sometimes fractious debate on the merits or demerits of the proposed Dell Inc. buyout, decision time nears for the company’s shareholders. Investors have until July 18 to tender their stock to Michael Dell in his proposed $13.65-a-share deal that the special committee of Dell’s board has overseen.

articles.headline: For Solazyme, a Side Trip on the Way to Clean Fuel
articles.snippet: A company wants to turn algae into energy. But first it has to make money, so it is developing other products from its algae-derived oils.
articles.abstract: A company wants to turn algae into energy. But first it has to make money, so it is developing other products from its algae-derived oils.
articles.lead_paragraph: STARTING when they became friends in freshman year at Emory University in Atlanta, Jonathan S. Wolfson and Harrison F. Dillon would take off into the mountains of Wyoming and Colorado for weeks at time. They spent their days hiking in the wilderness and their nights drinking bourbon by the campfire, talking big about how one day they would build a company that would help preserve the environment they both loved.

articles.headline: A Louisville Clinic Races to Adapt to the Health Care Overhaul
articles.snippet: To follow how the health care overhaul is playing out, The Times will look periodically at its impact in Louisville, Ky., a city that embodies the triumphs and the shortcomings of the medical system.
articles.abstract: To follow how the health care overhaul is playing out, The Times will look periodically at its impact in Louisville, Ky., a city that embodies the triumphs and the shortcomings of the medical system.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — One morning last month, a health clinic next to a scruffy strip mall here had an unlikely visitor: a man in a suit and tie, seeking to bring a dose of M.B.A. order to the operation.

articles.headline: Son and Heir? In Britain, Daughters Cry No Fair
articles.snippet: Male-only inheritance has Britain looking at whether its aristocracy is an essential part of its identity, a quaint vestige of the past or a bit of both.
articles.abstract: Male-only inheritance has Britain looking at whether its aristocracy is an essential part of its identity, a quaint vestige of the past or a bit of both.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Viewers of “Downton Abbey” spotted the family-destroying potential of primogeniture in the first episode, when the Titanic sank and Lord Grantham, father of three daughters, was left with no obvious heir.

articles.headline: Supreme Court Weighs Cases Redefining Legal Equality
articles.snippet: Four blockbuster cases before the Supreme Court highlight the tension between formal equality and a more dynamic kind of equality that takes account of historical injustices.
articles.abstract: Four blockbuster cases before the Supreme Court highlight the tension between formal equality and a more dynamic kind of equality that takes account of historical injustices.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Within days, the Supreme Court is expected to issue a series of decisions that could transform three fundamental social institutions: marriage, education and voting.

articles.headline: Mexico Pursuing Vanished Victims of Its Drug Wars
articles.snippet: In Nuevo León State, the authorities are doing the basic police work that is so often missing in this country, leaving countless crimes unsolved and unpunished.
articles.abstract: In Nuevo León State, the authorities are doing the basic police work that is so often missing in this country, leaving countless crimes unsolved and unpunished.
articles.lead_paragraph: MONTERREY, Mexico — Rosa González cannot shake the memory of the state investigator who was too afraid of reprisals to take a full report, the police officer who shrugged when the ransom demand came, the months of agonizing doubt and, most of all, the final words from her daughter before she disappeared.

articles.headline: Following a Star, Kerry Applies Personal Touch
articles.snippet: While his predecessor, Hillary Rodham Clinton, was a global celebrity, Secretary of State John Kerry is striving to carve out a legacy by taking on some of the world’s intractable problems.
articles.abstract: While his predecessor, Hillary Rodham Clinton, was a global celebrity, Secretary of State John Kerry is striving to carve out a legacy by taking on some of the world’s intractable problems.
articles.lead_paragraph: DOHA, Qatar — Secretary of State John Kerry flew to Moscow early last month, determined to involve Russia in a new push to try to end the carnage in Syria. After a two-and-a-half-hour meeting with the Russian president, Vladimir V. Putin, and a private stroll with Sergey V. Lavrov, the Russian foreign minister, the two sides announced they would convene a conference in Geneva to bring representatives of the Syrian government together with the opposition, possibly by the end of May.

articles.headline: Snowden, in Russia, Seeks Asylum in Ecuador
articles.snippet: Edward J. Snowden arrived in Moscow on Sunday as American officials pressed Russia to turn him over and warned countries in Latin America not to harbor him or allow him passage.
articles.abstract: Edward J. Snowden arrived in Moscow on Sunday as American officials pressed Russia to turn him over and warned countries in Latin America not to harbor him or allow him passage.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The American authorities scrambled Sunday to figure out how to catch Edward J. Snowden, the former national security contractor accused of espionage, as he led them on an international chase, frustrating the Obama administration and threatening to strain relations on three continents.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Ellen Barry

articles.headline: Disruptions: Medicine That Monitors You
articles.snippet: Scientists, researchers and some start-ups are preparing the next, even more intrusive wave of computing: ingestible computers and sensors in pills.
articles.abstract: Scientists, researchers and some start-ups are preparing the next, even more intrusive wave of computing: ingestible computers and sensors in pills.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — They look like normal pills, oblong and a little smaller than a daily vitamin. But if your doctor writes a prescription for these pills in the not-too-distant future, you might hear a new twist on an old cliché: “Take two of these ingestible computers, and they will e-mail me in the morning.”

articles.headline: Employers Test Plans That Cap Health Costs
articles.snippet: Companies are testing medical plans that limit what they will pay for certain procedures, encouraging employees to choose less expensive hospitals.
articles.abstract: Companies are testing medical plans that limit what they will pay for certain procedures, encouraging employees to choose less expensive hospitals.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hoping to cut medical costs, employers are experimenting with a new way to pay for health care, telling workers that their company health plan will pay only a fixed amount for a given test or procedure, like a CT scan or knee replacement. Employees who choose a doctor or hospital that charges more are responsible for paying the additional amount themselves.

articles.headline: Google Ventures Stresses Science of Deal, Not Art of the Deal
articles.snippet: Since its founding in 2009, Google Ventures has stood out in an industry whose track record has trailed the stock markets at large.
articles.abstract: Since its founding in 2009, Google Ventures has stood out in an industry whose track record has trailed the stock markets at large.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Here is how the venture capital game used to be played around here:

articles.headline: Hulu Faces a Nebulous Future as It Seeks a New Owner
articles.snippet: Hulu’s sale could signal the end of one of the pioneers of online streaming, which has become an increasingly popular way to watch television.
articles.abstract: Hulu’s sale could signal the end of one of the pioneers of online streaming, which has become an increasingly popular way to watch television.
articles.lead_paragraph: This year Hulu reached a milestone: viewers streamed more than one billion videos on the site in a single three-month period.
articles.byline: By Amy Chozick and Brian Stelter

articles.headline: British Invasion Reshuffles U.S. Media
articles.snippet: The observation about the proliferation of British talent in the American media landscape is hardly new, but something is at work here.
articles.abstract: The observation about the proliferation of British talent in the American media landscape is hardly new, but something is at work here.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Thursday night, the host of “The Daily Show” riffed on Paula Deen’s liberal use of both butter and racial slurs, chatted about journalism with Tom Brokaw and parodied the gangster code of honor that has been in the news in the Whitey Bulger trial. Along the way, he did a honey-dripped Southern accent and dropped into a Cagney-esque wiseguy voice.

articles.headline: Brazil, Fortune and Fate Turn on Billionaire
articles.snippet: Once worth $34.5 billion, Eike Batista’s holdings are now estimated at $4.8 billion and falling. With Brazil’s streets churning in protest, the markets — and Mr. Batista’s fortune — are on uncertain terrain.
articles.abstract: Once worth $34.5 billion, Eike Batista’s holdings are now estimated at $4.8 billion and falling. With Brazil’s streets churning in protest, the markets — and Mr. Batista’s fortune — are on uncertain terrain.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the Brazilian billionaire Eike Batista appeared on the Charlie Rose show in 2010, he and his country were on a roll.
articles.byline: By Peter Lattman and Simon Romero

articles.headline: N.S.A. Leak Puts Focus on System Administrators
articles.snippet: From government agencies to corporate America, there is a renewed emphasis on thwarting the rogue I.T. employee.
articles.abstract: From government agencies to corporate America, there is a renewed emphasis on thwarting the rogue I.T. employee.
articles.lead_paragraph: Edward J. Snowden, the former National Security Agency contractor who leaked details about American surveillance, personifies a debate at the heart of technology systems in government and industry: can the I.T. staff be trusted?
articles.byline: By Christopher Drew and Somini Sengupta

articles.headline: States Reined In by 1965 Voting Act Await a Decision
articles.snippet: A Supreme Court ruling on a key provision of the Voting Rights Act could have a dramatic effect on the low-profile world of county commissions and school boards.
articles.abstract: A Supreme Court ruling on a key provision of the Voting Rights Act could have a dramatic effect on the low-profile world of county commissions and school boards.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEAUMONT, Tex. — There is little agreement on anything, even when it all started, but sometime in the last decade the Beaumont Independent School District became a battle zone.

articles.headline: Offering Snowden Aid, WikiLeaks Gets Back in the Game
articles.snippet: WikiLeaks assisted Edward J. Snowden in his escape from Hong Kong and is providing legal assistance, placing the organization back in the global spotlight.
articles.abstract: WikiLeaks assisted Edward J. Snowden in his escape from Hong Kong and is providing legal assistance, placing the organization back in the global spotlight.
articles.lead_paragraph: WikiLeaks once again seized the global spotlight on Sunday by assisting Edward J. Snowden in his daring flight from Hong Kong, mounting a bold defense of the culture of national security disclosures that it has championed and that has bedeviled the United States and other governments.

articles.headline: Leaker’s Flight Raises Tension Between U.S. and 3 Nations
articles.snippet: The Obama administration escalated its criticism on Monday of Russia, China and Ecuador, the countries that appeared to be protecting Edward J. Snowden, who is wanted on spying charges.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration escalated its criticism on Monday of Russia, China and Ecuador, the countries that appeared to be protecting Edward J. Snowden, who is wanted on spying charges.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Frustrated Obama administration officials pressed Russia on Monday to turn over Edward J. Snowden, the national security contractor who disclosed surveillance programs, while warning China of “consequences” for letting him flee to Moscow.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Ellen Barry

articles.headline: Mass Layoffs at a Top-Flight Law Firm
articles.snippet: The prestigious law firm Weil, Gotshal & Manges is laying off a large number of lawyers and support staff, as well as reducing the pay of some partners, a move that underscores the difficulties facing the legal profession.
articles.abstract: The prestigious law firm Weil, Gotshal & Manges is laying off a large number of lawyers and support staff, as well as reducing the pay of some partners, a move that underscores the difficulties facing the legal profession.
articles.lead_paragraph: Layoffs are a brutal reality of corporate America. During fallow periods, publicly traded companies, including the big banks, routinely cull their ranks. The country’s largest law firms, by contrast, have historically taken a kinder, gentler approach, rarely firing employees en masse.

articles.headline: Justices Step Up Scrutiny of Race in College Entry
articles.snippet: The 7-to-1 ruling was both modest and significant, and its recalibration of how courts review the programs is likely to give rise to a wave of challenges to college admissions decisions.
articles.abstract: The 7-to-1 ruling was both modest and significant, and its recalibration of how courts review the programs is likely to give rise to a wave of challenges to college admissions decisions.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Courts must take a skeptical look at affirmative-action programs at public colleges and universities, the Supreme Court ruled Monday, in a decision that is likely to set off a wave of challenges to race-conscious admissions policies nationwide.

articles.headline: Deals in the Works Involving 2 Luxury Retailers
articles.snippet: Neiman Marcus filed to go public on Monday, more than eight years after agreeing to go private in a sale to the investment firms TPG Capital and Warburg Pincus.
articles.abstract: Neiman Marcus filed to go public on Monday, more than eight years after agreeing to go private in a sale to the investment firms TPG Capital and Warburg Pincus.
articles.lead_paragraph: High-end fashion still has plenty of appeal for Wall Street as two of the biggest luxury brands tested their worth to the market.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Peter Lattman
